channel.title: NYT > World News
channel.copyright: Copyright 2023 The New York Times Company

item.title: Israel-Hamas War: Israeli Forces Step Up Bombardment and Make Another Incursion Into Gaza
item.description: Israeli military officials declined to say if the newest incursion was the start of an anticipated ground offensive. In New York, police arrested protesters after hundreds flooded Grand Central Terminal to demand a cease-fire.
item.dc:creator: The New York Times
item.media:description: Smoke rises after an Israeli airstrike in Beit Hanoun in the Gaza Strip on Friday.

item.title: In Rare Protest, Ukrainian Families Press for News on Missing
item.description: In a rare show of public criticism in wartime, families of missing Ukrainian soldiers are pressing the government for information on their status.
item.dc:creator: Carlotta Gall and Oleksandr Chubko
item.media:credit: Brendan Hoffman for The New York Times
item.media:description: Demonstrators gathered in Independence Square in Ukraine’s capital, Kyiv, this month to bring attention to soldiers who are missing in action.

item.title: Students on the Run, Schools Taken by Troops and a Generation’s Catastrophe
item.description: With an estimated 19 million children out of school for months because of war, Sudan is on the verge of becoming “the worst education crisis in the world,” U.N. officials say.
item.dc:creator: Abdi Latif Dahir
item.media:description: Refugees who fled the war in Sudan attended an English class at a refugee resettlement camp in Aweil, in South Sudan.

item.title: Former L’Oreal Scientist’s Paris Salons Specialize in Curly Hair, Neglected in France
item.description: With a Ph.D. in chemistry and inspired by her daughter, Aude Livoreil-Djampou is trying to address the dearth of salon options in France for people with coiled or curly hair.
item.dc:creator: Aida Alami
item.media:credit: Dmitry Kostyukov for The New York Times
item.media:description: Aude Livoreil-Djampou near one of her Paris hair salons, all of which specialize in textured or curly hair.

item.title: Saudi Arabia Warns U.S.: Israeli Invasion of Gaza Could Be Catastrophic
item.description: In discussions with their American counterparts, Saudi officials have framed a ground war as a potentially devastating blow to stability in the Middle East.
item.dc:creator: Kate Kelly, Vivian Nereim, Mark Mazzetti and Edward Wong
item.media:credit: Sergey Ponomarev for The New York Times
item.media:description: Israeli troops during an artillery drill in southern Israel on Monday.

item.title: Hamas Has Stock of Food, Water and Fuel As Gazans Scrounge for It
item.description: Hamas has spent years stockpiling desperately needed fuel, food and medicine, as well as ammo and weapons, in the miles of tunnels it has carved out under Gaza.
item.dc:creator: Matthew Rosenberg and Maria Abi-Habib
item.media:credit: Lynsey Addario for The New York Times
item.media:description: Palestinians receiving building materials through tunnels in Southern Gaza in 2011. The network is by now so established that Hamas can manufacture weapons underground, eliminating the need to smuggle them from Egypt.

item.title: Russia’s Central Bank Raises Rates to 15 Percent to Curb Inflation
item.description: The jump, from 13 percent, would bring a long period of “tight monetary conditions” in order to ease price pressures, the bank said.
item.dc:creator: Ivan Nechepurenko
item.media:credit: Nanna Heitmann for The New York Times
item.media:description: The Moscow City financial center, in August.

item.title: Berlusconi Bequeaths a Warehouse of Art Befitting the Man
item.description: The Italian media mogul bought up some 25,000 paintings, many on TV shopping binges, before he died this year. Now no one knows what to do with them.
item.dc:creator: Jason Horowitz and Elisabetta Povoledo
item.media:description: Silvio Berlusconi in Palazzo Grazioli, where he lived in Rome, in 2014.

item.title: Local Police in Ofakim Defended the Israeli City From Hamas’s Attacks
item.description: Military support was slow to arrive in the quiet desert city of Ofakim but officers, most of them armed with handguns, fought back.
item.dc:creator: Adam Goldman and Gal Koplewitz
item.media:credit: Sergey Ponomarev for The New York Times
item.media:description: Itamar Alus manning a checkpoint outside Ofakim, Israel, on Friday. He and several other local police officers defended the city from Hamas terrorists on Oct. 7.

item.title: One Year After the Itaewon Crowd Crush
item.description: Survivors of the Itaewon disaster and relatives of victims continue to wrestle with unanswered questions and grief as they push for official accountability.
item.dc:creator: Choe Sang-Hun and Chang W. Lee
item.media:description: A memorial to the victims was unveiled on Thursday in the cramped alley in Itaewon where the stampede occurred last year.

item.title: As Winter Nears, Ukraine Braces for Attacks on Energy Grid
item.description: Russia targeted power systems last year and recent attacks suggest a return to that strategy, raising anxiety among Ukrainian civilians and officials.
item.dc:creator: Marc Santora and Matthew Mpoke Bigg
item.media:description: The Khmelnytsky nuclear power plant in August. President Volodymyr Zelensky of Ukraine said it was “highly likely” that a Russian drone strike on Wednesday targeted the facility.

item.title: After Hurricane Otis, Mexican Officials Confirm At Least 27 Deaths
item.description: The storm was one of the strongest ever to hit the southwest coast, and the Mexican government dispatched thousands of troops to the region.
item.dc:creator: Zolan Kanno-Youngs, Emiliano Rodríguez Mega and Elda Cantú
item.media:description: Street stalls damaged by Hurricane Otis on the outskirts of Acapulco, Mexico, on Wednesday.

item.title: In Denmark, Eviction and Demolition Remake ‘Non-Western’ Neighborhoods
item.description: A government program is using demolition and relocation to remake neighborhoods with immigrants, poverty or crime.
item.dc:creator: Emma Bubola
item.media:credit: Charlotte de la Fuente for The New York Times
item.media:description: “I feel by removing us, they would like to hide us because we are foreigners,” said Nasrin Bahrampour, left, with her husband, Ali.

item.title: A Hindu Mardi Gras Where Indian Progressivism Is Alive and Well
item.description: A huge religious carnival shows that India remains a country of diverse political and social beliefs, despite the right-wing national government’s dominance.
item.dc:creator: Suhasini Raj and Atul Loke
item.media:description: The Durga Puja, the Bengal region’s biggest religious festival, concluded in Kolkata on Tuesday.

item.title: Protesters in NYC Overrun Grand Central to Call for a Cease-fire in Gaza
item.description: The demonstration, organized by Jewish Voice for Peace, called for a cease-fire in the Israel-Hamas war.
item.dc:creator: Claire Fahy, Julian Roberts-Grmela and Sean Piccoli
item.media:credit: Bing Guan for The New York Times
item.media:description: Protesters crowded into Grand Central Terminal in midtown Manhattan on Friday.

item.title: Israeli Forces Raid Gaza as Pressure Builds for Cease-Fire
item.description: Cellular and internet service abruptly vanished for much of the territory, stoking fears that a full-scale invasion was imminent — or already underway.
item.dc:creator: Patrick Kingsley, Ronen Bergman, Karen Zraick and Hiba Yazbek
item.category: United Nations Relief and Works Agency
item.media:description: A smoke plume ascending following Israeli bombardments on Friday over the northern Gaza Strip.

item.title: Many in Gaza Lose Phone and Internet Service as Israel Intensifies Attacks
item.description: Two major Palestinian mobile networks, Jawwal and Paltel, said that their phone lines and internet services were down.
item.dc:creator: Yousur Al-Hlou and Raja Abdulrahim
item.media:description: Explosions Friday over the northern Gaza Strip.

item.title: Iran’s Proxy Forces Across the Middle East
item.description: A “Shiite Crescent” stretches from Yemen on the Arabian Peninsula through Iraq, Syria and Lebanon and back down to the Gaza Strip.
item.dc:creator: Neil MacFarquhar
item.media:credit: James Hill for The New York Times
item.media:description: Supporters of Hezbollah protesting at the Lebanese-Israeli border in 2002 against an Israeli offensive in the West Bank.

item.title: U.S. Airstrikes Contain Twin Messages to Iran, American Officials Say
item.description: The airstrikes were the latest gamble by the United States to modify Iran’s behavior, few of which have worked in the past.
item.dc:creator: David E. Sanger and Julian E. Barnes
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.media:description: Defense Secretary Lloyd J. Austin III said that the United States “has no intention nor desire to engage in further hostilities” if the Iranian-backed attacks stop.

item.title: Iran’s Proxies Fire Back After U.S. Airstrikes
item.description: The tit-for-tat raises questions about whether groups backed by Iran can be deterred after a flurry of attacks targeting American troops.
item.dc:creator: Eric Schmitt and Helene Cooper
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.media:description: U.S. troops in northeastern Syria earlier this year. Near daily attacks this month have targeted U.S. troops in the area.

item.title: At Barcelona, Timing Is Everything
item.description: The Barcelona team that faces Real Madrid in Saturday’s Clásico will be marked by youth, mostly because the club’s dire straits meant it had to be.
item.dc:creator: Rory Smith
item.media:description: Welcome to the party, Marc Guiu.

item.title: U.S. Imposes New Sanctions to Cut Off Hamas Funding
item.description: The Biden administration also targeted the group’s Iranian supporters.
item.dc:creator: Alan Rappeport
item.media:description: Members of Hamas taking part in a rally in Gaza City in 2021.

item.title: Celine Dion ‘Siren Battles’ Prompt Complaints in New Zealand City
item.description: A subculture has developed among Pacific Islander communities based on who can blast music — often Ms. Dion’s songs — the loudest. Some call it too disruptive.
item.dc:creator: Mike Ives
item.media:description: Celine Dion songs have been a favorite at siren battles in Porirua, New Zealand, apparently because they are so high-pitched.

item.title: Biden Faces Backlash From Party’s Left Wing on Israel
item.description: As a raw divide over the war ripples through liberal America, a coalition of young voters and people of color is breaking with the president, raising new questions about his strength entering 2024.
item.dc:creator: Reid J. Epstein and Anjali Huynh
item.media:credit: Tom Brenner for The New York Times
item.media:description: President Biden is facing new resistance from an energized faction of his party that views the Palestinian cause in the context of social justice.

item.title: How Are You Preparing for a Summer of Fires?
item.description: As El Niño arrives, heralding dry weather, it feels like the whole country is on edge. We’d like to hear from readers in Australia.
item.dc:creator: Yan Zhuang
item.media:description: Land destroyed by fire near the town of Tara, Queensland, on Thursday.

item.title: Chinese Jet Flies Within 10 Feet of B-52, U.S. Says
item.description: The fighter jet neared a B-52 during a maneuver over the South China Sea on Tuesday night, the U.S. military said. China had no immediate response.
item.dc:creator: Mike Ives

item.title: Friday Briefing
item.description: Pressure builds for a pause in Gaza.
item.dc:creator: Jonathan Wolfe
item.media:description: The European Union headquarters in Brussels on Wednesday.

item.title: Li Keqiang, Former Chinese Premier, Dies of Heart Attack at 68
item.description: Mr. Li, who retired in March, was muscled out of the premier’s usual policymaking roles by Mr. Xi. Chinese citizens expressed shock at his death, from a heart attack.
item.dc:creator: Chris Buckley and Keith Bradsher
item.media:description: Li Keqiang in 2017. He was once considered a potential top leader of the Chinese Communist Party.

item.title: Jake Sullivan’s ‘Quieter’ Middle East Comments Did Not Age Well
item.description: The national security adviser has drawn criticism for recent public remarks. Biden officials pushed back on the idea that Mr. Sullivan was offering a lasting view on Middle East conflicts.
item.dc:creator: Katie Rogers
item.media:description: Jake Sullivan, President Biden’s national security adviser, at the White House earlier this month.

item.title: Gazans Release Names of 6,747 People They Say Were Killed in Israeli Strikes
item.description: The detailed list from the Hamas-controlled health ministry — including ages, genders and ID numbers — followed President Biden’s comment that he had “no confidence” in its figures.
item.dc:creator: Vivian Yee
item.media:credit: Yousef Masoud for The New York Times
item.media:description: Palestinians carrying the bodies of members of the Al-Satra family during their funeral on Thursday in Khan Younis, Gaza.

item.title: Israeli Tanks Raid Gaza Ahead of Invasion, While Aid Trickles In
item.description: The United States has advised delaying a ground invasion, in part to get more desperately needed aid, which has flowed slowly, into Gaza.
item.dc:creator: Nadav Gavrielov, Matthew Mpoke Bigg, Vivian Yee and Matina Stevis-Gridneff
item.media:credit: Sergey Ponomarev for The New York Times
item.media:description: Israeli soldiers seen during drills in Northern Israel, on Thursday.

item.title: Hamas Leaders Arrive in Russia as the Kremlin Attempts to Showcase Clout
item.description: The meetings with high-ranking members of the group that attacked Israel underscored how Russia is trying to present itself as an alternative platform for possible mediation.
item.dc:creator: Ivan Nechepurenko
item.media:description: Moussa Abu Marzouk, a senior Hamas official, in 2014. A group of high-ranking members of Hamas arrived in Moscow on Thursday, meeting with a senior Russian official.

item.title: Friday Briefing: Israel Says Tanks Briefly Entered Gaza
item.description: Plus inspiration in the Rugby World Cup final.
item.dc:creator: Justin Porter
item.category: Far East, South and Southeast Asia and Pacific Areas
item.media:credit: Israeli Army, via Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: Footage provided by the Israeli Army on Thursday showing what it said were tanks and infantry in northern Gaza.

item.title: Disagreements Among Israeli Leaders Delay Gaza Ground Invasion
item.description: In the 20 days since Hamas attacked, Israel’s Air Force has pounded Gaza and its troops have gotten into position. But its leaders disagree about what to do next.
item.dc:creator: Patrick Kingsley and Ronen Bergman
item.media:credit: Sergey Ponomarev for The New York Times
item.media:description: Israeli military vehicles near the Gaza Strip this week.

item.title: Air Canada Apologizes for Questioning a British Lawmaker About His Background
item.description: The airline and Canadian immigration officials were accused of singling out the lawmaker, Mohammad Yasin, “because his name was Mohammad.”
item.dc:creator: Isabella Kwai
item.media:description: Air Canada said it apologized after Mohammad Yasin, a British lawmaker, was singled out for questioning while on a business trip to Canada with other lawmakers.

item.title: Slovakia to Halt Arms Deliveries to Ukraine, as New Leader Promised
item.description: The newly appointed prime minister, Robert Fico, whose party aligned with pro-Russian forces during the recent election campaign, had promised “not to send a single cartridge” of ammunition to Kyiv.
item.dc:creator: Andrew Higgins
item.media:description: Prime Minister Robert Fico of Slovakia arriving on Thursday before the start of an E.U. leaders’ summit in Brussels.

item.title: What to Know About UNRWA, the Largest Aid Organization in Gaza
item.description: Established to provide temporary relief for Palestinians who fled or were expelled from their homes during the 1948 Arab-Israeli war, the agency now mainly provides services and funding for those registered as Palestinian refugees across the Mideast.
item.dc:creator: Monika Pronczuk
item.category: United Nations Relief and Works Agency
item.media:credit: Samar Abu Elouf for The New York Times
item.media:description: A camp run by the United Nations Relief Works Agency in Khan Younis, in southern Gaza, for Palestinians displaced from Gaza City.

item.title: Israel-Hamas War Looms Over Saudi Arabia Forum
item.description: The kingdom is embracing business as usual, hosting an investment forum, concerts and even fashion shows. But grief, fear and outrage over Israel’s bombardment of Gaza simmer just below the surface.
item.dc:creator: Vivian Nereim, Kate Kelly and Ahmed Al Omran
item.media:description: Attendees at a Saudi investment conference in the capital, Riyadh, on Tuesday.

item.title: As Violence Surges, Nations Seek U.S. Defense Pacts. Some Americans Are Wary.
item.description: Many countries, including Ukraine and Israel, want greater U.S. protection against Russia, China, Iran and North Korea. But some Americans resist further military commitments.
item.dc:creator: Edward Wong
item.media:description: President Biden has reinforced the case to Americans for military aid to Ukraine and Israel.

item.title: Who Is in Israel’s War Cabinet?
item.description: Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu said that the small group of officials would play a key role in determining when Israel begins a ground invasion of Gaza.
item.dc:creator: Aaron Boxerman
item.media:credit: Tamir Kalifa for The New York Times
item.media:description: A house in Kibbutz Be’eri that was damaged during the Hamas attack.

item.title: Dave Chappelle Laments ‘Nightmare’ Facing Israelis and Palestinians
item.description: The comedian, whose remarks about the Israel-Hamas war last week made headlines, returned to the subject at a show in North Carolina.
item.dc:creator: Jonathan Abrams
item.media:description: Dave Chappelle at Madison Square Garden in New York City in August. He appeared in Raleigh, N.C., on Wednesday.

item.title: South Korea Must Return Buddhist Statue to Japan, Supreme Court Says
item.description: The artifact, which was taken to Tsushima centuries ago, was stolen and smuggled back to South Korea by thieves in 2012.
item.dc:creator: Choe Sang-Hun
item.media:credit: Ko Sasaki for The New York Times
item.media:description: A photograph of the Buddhist statue, which represents a bodhisattva known as Kanzeon in Japan and Gwaneum in South Korea.

item.title: Thursday Briefing
item.description: Biden calls for more aid into Gaza.
item.dc:creator: Jonathan Wolfe
item.media:description: President Joe Biden speaking during a press conference at the White House on Wednesday.

item.title: Biden Keeps Australia’s Dinner Low-Key at a Moment of Global Turmoil
item.description: Before the state dinner was over, President Biden had stepped out for a briefing on a mass shooting in Maine and to call lawmakers in the state. He left shortly after 10 p.m.
item.dc:creator: Katie Rogers
item.media:description: The U.S. Marine Band and the Army and Air Force Strolling Strings played at Wednesday night’s state dinner instead of the B-52s.

item.title: Several Family Members of Al Jazeera’s Gaza Bureau Chief Are Killed
item.description: Wael al-Dahdouh, described by his colleagues as “the voice of Palestinians in Gaza,” lost his wife, son, daughter and infant grandson, Al Jazeera said.
item.dc:creator: Anushka Patil and Gaya Gupta

item.title: Hurricane Otis Batters Mexico, Defying Forecasts
item.description: Hurricane Otis defied forecasts when it quickly transformed from a tropical storm into a Category 5 storm and slammed into the coastal city of Acapulco.
item.dc:creator: Zolan Kanno-Youngs, Judson Jones and Derrick Bryson Taylor

item.title: Turkey’s Erdogan Defends Hamas and Lashes Out at Israel
item.description: In a speech in Parliament, President Recep Tayyip Erdogan of Turkey accused Israel of committing “massacres” in Gaza and said Hamas was fighting for “liberation.”
item.dc:creator: Ben Hubbard and Safak Timur
item.media:description: President Recep Tayyip Erdogan of Turkey in Ankara on Wednesday.

item.title: U.S. Seeks Delay in Israel’s Gaza Ground Invasion to Bolster Air Defenses
item.description: The systems would allow the United States to provide more protection for American troops at bases in Iraq, Syria and elsewhere.
item.dc:creator: David E. Sanger and Eric Schmitt
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.media:credit: Sergey Ponomarev for The New York Times
item.media:description: Israeli soldiers on Wednesday. Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu of Israel said he “won’t detail all the considerations we’re taking into account, most of them totally unknown to the public.”

item.title: Carnival Was Negligent in Covid Outbreak on Cruise Ship, Court Rules
item.description: An Australian judge found that the cruise company and a subsidiary “breached their duty of care” in handling a coronavirus outbreak on the Ruby Princess in March 2020.
item.dc:creator: Michael Levenson
item.media:description: The Ruby Princess cruise ship departing Port Kembla in Wollongong, Australia, in April 2020.

item.title: Thursday Briefing: Gaza Is Running Out of Fuel
item.description: Plus Vietnam’s many cable cars.
item.dc:creator: Justin Porter
item.category: Far East, South and Southeast Asia and Pacific Areas
item.media:credit: Samar Abu Elouf for The New York Times
item.media:description: A water filling station in the city of Khan Younis in Gaza on Tuesday.

item.title: From Gaza, an Audio Diary of Despair
item.description: In a series of voice memos sent via WhatsApp, Tasneem Ismael Ahel, 19, described the war unfolding around her in Gaza City.
item.dc:creator: Yousur Al-Hlou

item.title: With Fuel Shortages in Gaza, U.N. Aid Group May Shut Down Operations
item.description: A U.N. agency that has offered a wartime lifeline to hundreds of thousands of Palestinians warned of “tough decisions” ahead if it cannot get fuel.
item.dc:creator: Monika Pronczuk
item.category: United Nations Relief and Works Agency
item.media:credit: Samar Abu Elouf for The New York Times
item.media:description: In the Gaza Strip, many filling stations, like this one in Khan Younis on Wednesday, have run out of fuel and closed.

item.title: Israel’s Strikes on Gaza Are Some of the Most Intense This Century
item.description: In the 19 days since Hamas attacked Israel, the Israeli military says it has struck more than 7,000 targets in Gaza. Palestinians accuse Israel of indiscriminately targeting civilians, but Israel officials say the strikes are aimed at eroding military infrastructure.
item.dc:creator: Patrick Kingsley
item.media:credit: Yousef Masoud for The New York Times
item.media:description: Gazans assess the damage from an Israeli airstrike in Khan Younis, Gaza, on Wednesday.

item.title: Ex-Fashion Executive, Peter Nygard, Testifies in His Sexual Assault Trial
item.description: A lawyer for Peter Nygard, a former fashion executive accused of sexually assaulting five women, described their testimony as “revisionist history.’’
item.dc:creator: Vjosa Isai
item.media:description: Peter Nygard arriving at court in Toronto in September.

item.title: Biden Reaffirms Support for Israel but Calls for Protection of Civilians
item.description: During an appearance with the Australian prime minister, President Biden pledged that the United States would provide Israel with what it needed to defend itself against Hamas.
item.dc:creator: Katie Rogers
item.media:description: President Biden speaking during a joint press conference with Prime Minister Anthony Albanese of Australia.

item.title: Shoplifting Surges in U.K., and Workers Face Scary Situations
item.description: As people try to walk away with goods, it’s “like the Wild West,” says one store owner, whose employees have been hit and bitten on the job.
item.dc:creator: Stephen Castle
item.media:credit: Andrew Testa for The New York Times
item.media:description: Richard Inglis, the owner of three Welcome grocery stores in Southampton, England, checking security camera footage at one of his shops.

item.title: Chasing Big Mergers, Oil Executives Dismiss Peak Oil Concerns
item.description: Exxon Mobil and Chevron are spending tens of billions of dollars buying oil and gas assets, betting that the International Energy Agency’s predictions of declining oil demand are wrong.
item.dc:creator: Clifford Krauss
item.media:credit: Tamir Kalifa for The New York Times
item.media:description: ExxonMobil’s acquisition of Pioneer Natural Resources creates a shale oil behemoth in the Permian Basin, the heart of the Texas and New Mexico oil patch.

item.title: Biden Seeks to Tame Oil Prices if Mideast Conflict Sends Them Soaring
item.description: The president has previously drawn down the Strategic Petroleum Reserve to ease price pressures, but that could be more difficult now
item.dc:creator: Jim Tankersley and Ben Casselman
item.media:description: Oil tankers at one of the largest facilities in Russia. Russia has found ways around the price cap, forcing officials to take steps to crack down on enforcement of the cap in hopes of reducing the price at which Russian oil is sold.

item.title: What I Read and Watch to Decompress
item.description: Some Jane Austen and a tennis rom-com are just right the right relief when news of fighting and war takes a toll.
item.dc:creator: Amanda Taub
item.category: War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity
item.media:description: Kirsten Dunst as Lizzie Bradbury in the 2004 film “Wimbledon.”

item.title: Why Hurricane Otis Caught Many By Surprise
item.description: Storms don’t normally go from a tropical storm to a Category 5 hurricane in a day.
item.dc:creator: Judson Jones
